localizedDescriptions.en: Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
A group of observations that are recorded at the same time and record the blood pressure, pulse, temperature and other readings.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.  Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
Record details about the rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The pulse rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Is the pulse or heart beat regular?
Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Additional narrative about the pulse or heart beat findings not captured in other fields.
The body position of the subject during the observation.
The subject was standing, walking or running.
The subject was sitting (for example on bed or chair).
The subject was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
Narrative description about any incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the physical findings.

annotations.comment: For example, presence of a pacemaker, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.

localizedDescriptions.en: Maximum pulse rate or heart rate observed during a period of exertion.

annotations.comment: It can be implied that the pulse is present if Rate >0 beats/min.

localizedDescriptions.en: A pulse or heart beat can be detected.
A pulse or heart beat cannot be detected.

annotations.comment: It can be implied that the pulse is present if Rate >0 beats/min.

localizedDescriptions.en: A pulse or heart beat can be detected.
A pulse or heart beat cannot be detected.
The pulse rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: The heart rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Is the pulse or heart beat regular?
More specific pattern of an irregular pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Selection of a value from this value set is only valid if 'Irregular' is selected from the 'Regularity' data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: The pattern is irregular in a regular pattern,. For example, a dropped beat once every 'n' beats.
The pattern is irregular in a chaotic and unpredictable manner. For example, atrial fibrillation.
Description of the character of the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desired, where possible. For example: full, thready, bounding, slow rising, or collapsing. Multiple terms may be recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Generic label to allow for any or all statements about the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Specific conclusion about the rhythm of the pulse or heartbeat, drawn from a combination of the heart rate, pattern and other characteristics observed on examination.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the pulse or heart beat findings not captured in other fields.
The body position of the subject during the observation.
The subject was standing, walking or running.
The subject was sitting (for example on bed or chair).
The subject was reclining at an approximate angle of 45 degrees, with the legs elevated to the level of the pelvis.
Narrative description about any incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the physical findings.

annotations.comment: For example, presence of a pacemaker, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.

localizedDescriptions.en: Method used to observe the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: For example, auscultation or electronic monitoring.

localizedDescriptions.en: The findings are observed by physical touch of the observer on the subject.
The findings are observed with the assistance of a device, such as a stethoscope.
The findings are observed non-invasively using a device such as a pulse oximeter or a stethoscope.
The findings are observed invasively using a device such as an arterial catheter.
Body site where the pulse or heart beat were observed.
The lobe of an unspecified ear.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Archetype to record a persisting summary or overview of use or consumption of tobacco over time.
Person is a current user of tobacco
Person a former or ex-user of tobacco on a regular basis
Person a former or ex-user of tobacco on a regular basis
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
An electrocardiograph (ECG) is an interpretation of the electrical activity of the heart over time, recorded non-invasively using external skin electrodes.
Measured interval from onset of P wave to QRS.

QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to
the ST segment onset (J point).
Lead I is the voltage between the (positive) left arm (LA) electrode and right arm (RA) electrode.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead II is the voltage between the (positive) left leg (LL) electrode and the right arm (RA) electrode.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead III is the voltage between the (positive) left leg (LL) electrode and the left arm (LA) electrode.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.

Lead augmented vector right (aVR) has the positive electrode (white) on the right arm. The negative electrode is a combination of the left arm (black) electrode and the left leg (red) electrode, which "augments" the signal strength of the positive electrode on the right arm.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.

Lead augmented vector left (aVL) has the positive (black) electrode on the left arm. The negative electrode is a combination of the right arm (white) electrode and the left leg (red) electrode, which "augments" the signal strength of the positive electrode on the left arm.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.

Lead augmented vector foot (aVF) has the positive (red) electrode on the left leg. The negative electrode is a combination of the right arm (white) electrode and the left arm (black) electrode, which "augments" the signal of the positive electrode on the left leg.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead V1 is a precordial lead, placed in the fourth intercostal space (between ribs 4 & 5) just to the right of the sternum (breastbone).
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead V2 is a precordial lead, placed in the fourth intercostal space (between ribs 4 & 5) just to the left of the sternum.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead V3 is a precordial lead, placed in between leads V2 and V4.
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.

Lead V4 is a precordial lead, placed in the fifth intercostal space (between ribs 5 & 6) in the mid-clavicular line (the imaginary line that extends down from the midpoint of the clavicle (collarbone).
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.

Lead V5 is a precordial lead, placed horizontally even with V4, but in the anterior axillary line. (The anterior axillary line is the imaginary line that runs down from the point midway between the middle of the clavicle and the lateral end of the clavicle; the lateral end of the collarbone is the end closer to the arm).
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Lead V6 is a precordial lead, placed horizontally even with V4 and V5 in the midaxillary line. (The midaxillary line is the imaginary line that extends down from the middle of the patient's armpit).
P wave area for monophasic P waves or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Ventricular Activation Time is the interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
QRS complex duration, measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).
The area of the QRS complex.
Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.
ST segment slope. Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
The ST segment is concave upward.
The ST segment is concave downward.
Interpretative comment on this recording originating from the device.
An overall interpretative comment on this recording.
Pulmonary function testing including spirometry and other lung volume testing.
Details of Pulmonary Function Test Results.
Pulmonary function test that returns a measured volume or caclulated capacity.
The name of the pulmonary volume test/parameter.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in one second.
The ratio of actual to predicted test result.
A pulmonary function test result expressed as a ratio.
The nameof the pulmonary ratio test.
The ration of Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to Forced vital capacity.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may affect interpretation of the observation.
The body position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of measurement.
Reclining at the time of measurement.
Lying flat at the time of measurement.
Details of any bronchial challenge administered as part of the test.
The agent or physical modality used e.g exercise.
The dose of agent used in the test.
The test was taken before  the challenge.
The test was performed after the bronchial challenge.
The timing of the test in relation to the challenge.
Details of bronchodilation administered as part of the test.
The bronchodilating agent used in the test.
The dose of agent used in the test.
The test was taken before  the challenge.
The test was performed after the bronchial challenge.
The timing of the test in relation to the challenge.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.
A desired health, or well-being, outcome for the subject of care.
The name of the desired health outcome.

annotations.comment: For example: reduced blood pressure; 10 kilogram weight loss; or diabetes control.

localizedDescriptions.en: A narrative description of the goal, including target/s to be achieved if relevant.
Name of the problem or diagnosis which is intended to be impacted by achievement of this goal.

annotations.comment: For example: Hypertension; Obesity; or Diabetes Type 2.

localizedDescriptions.en: The anticipated or proposed date for commencing work towards the goal.

annotations.comment: Note: this date may not be the date of recording of the goal.

localizedDescriptions.en: The desired or proposed date for achieving the goal.
The actual date that the goal was achieved or abandoned.
Single word, phrase or brief description which represents the outcome actually achieved for the goal.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: target weight achieved; poor diabetes control; or successful completion.

localizedDescriptions.en: The proposed goal was partially realised.
The proposed goal was not realised and abandoned.
Additional narrative about the goal not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the reason why the goal was not achieved, or a description about how the goal was partially achieved.

Multiple targets are allowed. In some situations, only one target will be required. In some clinical scenarios the goal may require a multifaceted approach with a number of targets contributing to a successful goal outcome. In addition, some goals may require incremental targets to be set sequentially during a period of time.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the intended target, by name.

annotations.comment: For example: systolic blood pressure under 140 mmHg; lose 10 kilograms; or HBA1c in the normal range.

localizedDescriptions.en: The archetype and path to the node for target data.

annotations.comment: For example: the 'Weight' data element in the OBSERVATION.body_weight archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: The desired or proposed date for achieving the target.
The actual date that the target was achieved or abandoned.
Additional narrative about the target not captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: the reason why the target was not achieved, or a description about how the target was partially achieved.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date on which the goal was last updated.
